problem_text:
We call a metric space narrow if it is quasiisometric to a subset of the real line, and wide otherwise. Let G be a group with the finite set of generators A, and let Γ = Γ(G, A) be the Cayley graph of G with the natural metric. Suppose that, after deleting any narrow subset L from Γ, at most two connected components of the graph Γ\L can be wide, and there exists at least one such a subset L yielding exactly two wide components in Γ \ L. Is it true that Γ is quasiisometric to an Euclidean or a hyperbolic plane?
V. A. Churkin
answer: No, it is not true in general (O. V. Bogopol’skii, Preprint, Novosibirsk, 1998 (Russian)). See also new problem 14.98.
